title: Jack Watkins
text:
Jack Cosgrove "Bluey" Watkins (1893-1974) was an Australian <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer.
Career.
He played , with seven test matches for his country, including the <a href="1921%E2%80%9322%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain">1921–22 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain</a>. He is listed on the "Australian Players Register" as Kangaroo No. 92.
Watkins played for just one club in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20premiership">New South Wales Rugby Football League premiership</a> throughout his career which spanned 14 years, interrupted by the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. He played in over 100 matches for the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Eastern Suburbs</a> side between 1913 and 1926, winning <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">Premierships</a> with that club in 1913 and 1923. Watkins also won City Cups with the Easts club in 1914, 1915 and 1916.
After enlisting in the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, Watkins was chosen to play a series of matches for <a href="First%20Australian%20Imperial%20Force">Australian Imperial Forces</a> (AIF) against <a href="England">England</a>.
Bluey Watkins died on 13 July 1974, age 82.
